div.l: For thefte and ryot they be conủersible
All one he pleye on guyt̉erne or rybible
Reuel and trouth as in lowe degree
They be full wroth all day as men may see
This ioly p̉rentys with his Maist̉ers boode
Till he wer͗e nygh out of his app̉rentyshoodeapp̉rentyhoodeapp̉rentyshoode
All were he snybbed erly and late
And somtyme led wᵗith Reuel to newgate
But at þe last his Maister hym bythought
Vpon a day when his paper sought
Of a ꝓproủerbe that seith this same woord
Weel better is roten̄ appul out of hoord
Than it schuld roten all þe remenaıı̄unt
So fareth as by a Ryatous ʆseruᵃaunt
It is full lesse harme for to lete hym passe
Thanne he shende all þe ʆseruᵃauntꝭes in the place
Therfor͗e his Maister gaf hym acquitaunce
And bad hym goo with sorwe and myschaunce
And thus this Ioly app̉rentice had his leve
Now lete hym ryot all þe nyght or leve
And for þ̉er is no thief with out a looke
That helpeth hym to waste and to souke
Of þat he brybe can or borwe may
O none he sente his bedde and his array
Vnto a Comper of his owen̄ sorte
That loued dyce revel and disporte
And had a wyfe þat he held for countynaıı̄unce
A shoppe and swyved for hir sustenaıı̄unce
But here of I wole passe as now
And of yong Gamelyn̄ I wole telle yow

The Tale of yong Gamelyn̄ tolde by
the Coke of London̄
Lythe and listeneth and herkenyth a right
And ye shal here of a douty knyght
Sir Iohn̄ of was his name
He coude of norture and of moche game
Thre sones the knyght had of his body thanne
The eldest was a moche shrewe and sone he by ganne
His brothern̄ loued weel her fader and of hym were were agaste
The eldest deʆserued his fad̉ers curs and had it at þᵉ laste
The good knyght his fader lyved so ȝore
Þat deth was comen̄ hȳm to and handeled hym ful sore
The good knyght cared sore syke thẻre he laye
How his Children shuld lyven̄ after his daye
He had ben̄ wyde wher̉e but non husbond he was
Aƚƚ þe lond þat he had it was of purchas
Fayn he wold hit were dressed a mong hem alle
That eche of hem had his part as it myght falle
Thoo sent he in to the contre after wyse knyghtes
To helpe to dele his londis and dressen hem to rightes
He sente hem worde by łletres they shuld hye blyve
Yf they wold speke wᵗith hym whil he wer̉e on lyve
Thoo the knyghtes herden syke þat he lay
Had they no reste nouther nyght ne day
Tyl they come to hym ther he lay stylle
On his deth to abyden goddes wylle
Thanne seid the good knyght syke þer he lay
Lordes I yow warne forsoth with outen nay
I may no lenger lyven̄ here in this stounde
For thurgh goddes wil deth draw me to grounde
Ther̉e nas non of hem alle þat herde hym a right
But thay had ruthe of þat ilke knyght
And seid ʆser for goddes love ne dismay yow nought
God may di bote of bale that is now y wrought
Than spake the good knyght syke ther he lay
Bote of bale god may sende I wote it is no nay
But I beseke you knyghtes for the love of me
Goth and dresse my londes a monge my sones three
And for the love of god dele hem nat a mys
And for yete nat Gamelyn my yong that is
Take hede to the one as weel as to þe other
Selde ye seen̄ any heird helpen̄ his brother
Thoo leten they the knyght lyen este este þat was nat in hele
And wenten in to counseƚƚ his londes for to dele
For to delen̄ hem alle to one that was her thought
And For Gamelyn was þe yongest he shuld haue nout
Aƚƚ þe londe þat ther was they delte it in twoo
And leten̄ gamelyn the yong wᵗith out londe goo
And eche of them seid to other fuƚƚ lowde
Hys brothern̄ myght gef hym lond when he good coude
Whan they had deled the lond at he wyl
They come to the knyght there he lay foyll
And told hym a non how thei had wrought
And the knyght ther͗e he lay liked it right ro ro nought
Thanne seid knyght by seynt Martyne
For aƚƚ þat ye haue doıı̄un yet is þe lond myne
For goddes love neyboᵘurs stondeth alle stylle
And I wole dele my lond at myne owen wylle
